prompt: Please explain to me how deep learning works. Pretend I am a 7 year-old.
orig_response: Imagine you have a super smart friend who can look at lots of pictures and learn what they are. This friend is like a computer program called a "neural network." It's made up of many tiny "brain cells" that work together to figure things out. When you show the neural network a picture, it looks at the colors and shapes and says, "Oh, I think I see a cat!" But how does it know it's a cat? Well, the neural network looks at lots of pictures of cats and dogs and other things, and it starts to learn what makes a cat look like a cat. It's like it's learning a secret code that says, "If you see whiskers and pointy ears, it's probably a cat!" The more pictures it sees, the better it gets at recognizing cats and other things. And that's basically how deep learning works - it's like a super smart friend who gets better and better at recognizing things as it looks at more and more pictures.
